Theresa is 39 years old and lives in Montserrado County that is has the largest free-port and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is married with seven children between 14 and 25; unfortunately she did not go to school, but she manages her business well. 

For the past ten years she has been selling palm oil in the local market. She  started this business with money given to her by her husband who is a carpenter. She enjoys her business because the business gives her more money.  She sells six days a week, from 7am to 5pm, and most of the time she uses a bus to get her goods to her table. She is requesting a loan to purchase more palm oil for her business. Her plans are to build a house and own a shop.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for her business

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 40 years old, and lives in Montserrado County that has the largest free-port and is the number one commercial county in Liberia. She is a single woman with four children aged between 7 and 25; only two live at home and attend school.

Marie did not go to school. For the past 20 years she has been selling used clothes in the local market. She started this business with money given to her by her mother. She enjoys her business because the business gives her more money.  She sells six days a week, from 7am to 5pm, and most of the time she uses  taxi to get her goods to her shop. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. Her plans are to build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business

loans.name: Con Dios Adelante 3,  4 & 5 Group

texts.en:
Ines is a members of the Con Dios Adelante (God Bless) 3, 4 & 5 group, which has 15 micro-businesswomen. They are involved in sales of clothing, shoes, natural products, food, etc. Ines lives in the city of La Romana. Its economy depends on tourism and the sugarcane industry. The city has a sizable population of Dominicans and Haitian immigrants who live in communities with very limited resources.

Ines is very excited to receive her fourth loan from Esperanza International, having satisfactorily repaid her previous loan and taken an important step in her business's growth. She has had her business for about six years. She started it with her own capital, after she saved money by doing different jobs. She is running a shoes sales business, and she is planning on investing the new loan in buying many dozens of tennis shoes, sandals, sneakers and casual shoes for women, kids and men. She sells the shoes by walking around, from her house, and from a place in a flea market once a week.

Ines’s family is made up of herself and her two children. She tells us that her greatest challenge is to have her own house. She really enjoys working and taking care of her children. She will use her profits to invest in her business and to start saving, this time to make possible one of her dreams, to have her own house.

loans.use: to buy dozens of shoes to sell

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Nueva Esperanza  está en su primer ciclo 20º del programa de comité de mujeres, donde todas trabajan y se ayudan por salir adelante. Están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza para conocer la situación de cada una de ellas.
Francisca, una de las miembros, se dedica a las ventas, ya que tiene una despensa en su casa. Es por medio de este negocio que ella trabaja y ayuda a su familia dándoles lo que necesitan y que no pasen por privaciones.
Francisca solicita este crédito para invertirlo en la compra de verduras, fideos, arroz, yerba, azúcar y demás insumos de primera necesidad, ya que quiere seguir dando a sus clientes los productos que necesitan. Agradece por esta oportunidad que está recibiendo, ya que no solo ella se ve beneficiada, sino también toda su familia.
texts.en:
The group called Nueva Esperanza [New Hope] is in its 21st loan cycle of the Women's Committee program, where they all work and help each other to get ahead.  They are doing the poverty elimination survey to get to know each member's situation.

Francisca, one of the members, makes her living in sales and has a small store in her house.  It is through this business that she works and helps her family, giving them what they need and so that they don't want for anything.  

Francisca is applying for this loan in order to invest it in the purchase of vegetables, noodles, rice, tea, sugar and other basic needs, because she wants to continue giving her customers the products they need.  She is grateful for this opportunity she is receiving, since it is not only her that benefits, but also her whole family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, noodles, rice, tea, sugar, and more.

loans.name: Jovenes Emprendedores Group

texts.es:
El grupo denominado Jovenes Emprendedores está en su ciclo número 5 del programa de comité de jóvenes. Son 4 jóvenes que se unieron para poder trabajar juntos, generar un poco de ingresos para poder ayudar a su familia, y así sentirse útiles.
Karina es una de las integrantes, ella es presidenta la presidenta del grupo se dedica a la venta de comidas conjuntamente con su mama, y también estudia. Por medio de su esfuerzo por salir adelante ella logró mejorar su calidad de vida.  Ella tiene con su ingreso de su venta ambulante , solventa su gasto y su estudio  , recibe asistencia  permanente , asiste a reuniones de su comité, trabaja solidariamente con sus compañeros y mantiene  buen  pago con su grupo. Tienen la esperanza de ser el día de mañana grandes profesionales.
Karina solicita este crédito  para aumentar su venta, ya que necesita carne, verduras, harina, huevo y demás, con lo que podrá seguir haciendo sus comidas y vendiendo.
texts.en:
The group known as "Jovenes Emprendedores" (Enterprising Youth) are in their fifth loan cycle in the youth group program. They are four young people who came together so that they could work jointly, and generate a bit of of income to be able to help their families and feel useful. 

Karina is one of the members and is the chair of the group. She sells food with her mom and also goes to school. Through her effort to succeed, she has managed to improve her quality of life. With her income from her street vending, she has paid for her expenses and her studies. 

She receives on-going assistance, attends the group meetings, works supportively with her co-members, and maintains a good payment record with her group. They have the hope of someday being successful professionals. 

Karen is requesting this loan to increase her sales, as she needs meat, vegetables, flour, eggs and other items to enable her to keep making and selling her meals.

loans.use: To buy meat, vegetables, flour, eggs and other items.
